title: Epidemiology - FQE Jan 2024 | Past Papers
description: KMTC Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Health Records and Information Technology - Epidemiology Paper, January 2024

questions.question: As an epidemiologist, what would you consider as true about the susceptibility phase of a disease?
questions.explanation: Explanation: The Susceptibility Stage (Pre-pathogenesis) is characterized by the presence of risk factors (e.g., smoking, poor diet) but the disease process itself has not yet begun (No biological process, no symptoms).

options.text: A. Signs and symptoms of a disease are present
B. Biological process of the disease has started
C. Risk factors of the disease are present
D. There is some physical manifestation of the disease

questions.question: A public health officer decides to do conduct health promotion targeting lifestyle factors. Which method of disease prevention is he using?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Health promotion to prevent the onset of disease is Primary Prevention. If the action is at a policy level to prevent the emergence of the risk factors themselves (e.g., banning soda ads), it is Primordial. "Targeting lifestyle factors" usually falls under Primary (Health Promotion).

questions.question: Which branch of epidemiology investigates the association between a given disease and the causative factors of the same disease?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Analytic epidemiology is concerned with the "Why" and "How" – investigating associations and causes (determinants).

questions.question: Not everyone infected with Tuberculosis develops active disease. Other factors are needed to cause the disease. These factors are called
questions.explanation: Explanation: The TB bacteria is the Necessary cause. The other factors (malnutrition, HIV, overcrowding) that combine with it to produce disease are Component causes. Together they form a Sufficient cause.

questions.question: Counting is a key activity of epidemiologists. Which is the correct term that depicts the above statement?
questions.explanation: Explanation: "Counting cases" relates to quantifying the magnitude/occurrence, which is termed Disease Frequency.

questions.question: A patient was admitted in hospital suffering from pneumonia. During the patients stay in the hospital, he developed an infection. Such types of infections are called
questions.explanation: Explanation: Infections acquired during a hospital stay (that were not present on admission) are called Nosocomial (or Hospital-Acquired) infections.

questions.question: Handkerchiefs, drinking glasses, door handles, clothing and toys can convey infection to others when contaminated. Which is the correct name that refers to them?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Fomites are inanimate objects that can harbor and transmit infectious agents.

questions.question: A person infected with HIV/AIDS might not have the signs and symptoms but is capable of transmitting the infection to others. Which of the following terms correctly describe the above statement?
questions.explanation: Explanation: While the person is asymptomatic (B), the capability to transmit while infected without symptoms defines a Carrier (D). "Carrier" is the epidemiological role.

questions.question: Which one of the following is a zoonotic disease?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Rabies is a classic zoonosis transmitted from animals (dogs, bats) to humans. While COVID-19 has zoonotic origins, Rabies is the textbook example. Scabies is a mite infestation. Chicken pox is human-specific.

questions.question: During singing some saliva might land on the next person. If the saliva contains some disease agent, such transmission is called
questions.explanation: Explanation: This is typically called Droplet Spread. "Direct projection" is a synonym used in some older texts for the spray of droplets onto conjunctiva or mucous membranes. "Droplet nuclei" (B) implies airborne (long distance). Direct contact (A) implies skin-to-skin.

questions.question: The agent for malaria multiplies in the vector before transmission, such a vector is called?
questions.explanation: Explanation: If the agent undergoes multiplication or development (biological change) inside the vector (like Plasmodium in mosquitoes), it is a Biological Vector.

questions.question: A person consumed food at a birthday party and developed diarrhea. Which type of transmission is this that occurred through food or water he may have consumed
questions.explanation: Explanation: Food and water are inanimate intermediaries called Vehicles.

questions.question: Which measure of disease frequency is calculated by dividing the number of cases by the population at risk during the period of observation
questions.explanation: Explanation: "Number of cases / Population at risk" is the definition of Cumulative Incidence, which measures Risk. Rates usually involve person-time. However, colloquial usage often calls this a "Rate". "Risk" (D) is the most precise epidemiological term for probability.

questions.question: The total number of deaths during the year divided by the total population will result to what type of mortality rate
questions.explanation: Explanation: Total deaths / Total population = Crude Death Rate.

questions.question: Which one of the following is the correct numerator for cumulative incidence?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Incidence counts only NEW cases occurring during the study period.

options.text: A. Number of old & new cases in a specified time period
B. Number of new cases in a specified time period
C. Number of in new cases in a point in time
D. Number of new cases in unspecified time period

questions.question: While calculating prevalence of a disease, which is the correct denominator that you would apply?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Technically, prevalence uses the total population (often mid-year) including cases. However, "Total population at risk" is the general denominator concept for rates/proportions. Option A is for rates. Prevalence usually uses the total population at that time.

options.text: A. Total population in the mid-year
B. All cases irrespective of when they started
C. Disease free population at the start of period
D. Total population at risk of being a case

questions.question: Which is the basic measure of disease frequency
questions.explanation: Explanation: The count is the most basic measure.

questions.question: Which is the key term that differentiates an attack rate from incidence rate
questions.explanation: Explanation: An Attack Rate is a type of cumulative incidence used specifically for epidemics/outbreaks (short duration).

options.text: A. Number of new case reported during a given time
B. Number of new cases among the exposed
C. Number of new cases during an epidemic
D. Number of new cases among the population at risk

questions.question: The total number of deaths in the year were 100. The total number of deaths from HIV/AIDS were 30. The total number of cases of HIV were 200. Calculate the proportionate mortality rate of HIV/AIDS
questions.explanation: Calculation: PMR = (Deaths from HIV / Total Deaths) × 100 = (30 / 100) × 100 = 30%.

questions.question: The type of mortality rate that presents the killing power of a disease is called
questions.explanation: Explanation: CFR measures severity/virulence (killing power) among those who are sick.

questions.question: A population of 100 smokers were followed up for 10 years to ascertain their development of lung cancer. The correct study for the above situation is
questions.explanation: Explanation: Following a group (smokers) forward in time (10 years) to see outcomes is a Cohort Study.

questions.question: In a case control study, which of the following is true
questions.explanation: Explanation: Case-Control studies compare exposure history between Cases and Controls. Rates cannot be calculated directly (A).

options.text: A. Disease rates are compared among exposed & non exposed
B. The investigator may choose not to have multiple companion groups
C. The proportion of cases with exposure is compared with proportion in controls
D. Recall bias is not a potential problem

questions.question: The type of study designs that are employed to test specific etiological hypothesis and generate new etiological hypothesis are called
questions.explanation: Explanation: Analytic studies test hypotheses. Descriptive studies generate them.

questions.question: The process of making cases and controls equivalent with respect to factors other than exposure factors being investigated is called
questions.explanation: Explanation: In Case-Control studies, we Match controls to cases (e.g., by age/sex) to control for confounding.

questions.question: Loss to follow up is a major disadvantage in epidemiological studies. Which type of study is majorly affected by loss to follow up
questions.explanation: Explanation: Because Cohort studies run over long periods (years), participants often drop out (attrition bias).

questions.question: The type of errors that occur in epidemiology when there is a systematic difference between the characteristics of the people involved in the study are called
questions.explanation: Explanation: Systematic differences in who is in the study vs the target population is Selection Bias.

questions.question: Several sites have been identified for surveillance of HIV/AIDS. This type of surveillance is called
questions.explanation: Explanation: Selecting specific sites (sentinel sites) to monitor a disease (like HIV in antenatal clinics) is Sentinel Surveillance.

questions.question: Routine surveillance of TB data in a population can detect one of the following
questions.explanation: Explanation: Surveillance is best for monitoring trends over time.

options.text: B. Person variation of TB incidence
C. Current trends of TB incidence
D. Inconsistency of case detection rates

questions.question: Which one of the following diseases is surveillance required internationally?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Yellow Fever, Polio, and Cholera are typically international notifiable diseases under IHR.

questions.question: One of the following is a main disadvantage of active surveillance. Which one is it?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Active surveillance requires dedicated staff and resources, making it costly.

questions.question: Health workers are sometimes required to go to the field to collect data on a specific disease. Such type of surveillance is called
questions.explanation: Explanation: Going to the field/facilities to find data = Active.

questions.question: Surveillance officers need to develop systems to alert them about diseases in advance. The system can be referred to as
questions.explanation: Explanation: Systems designed to give advance alerts of outbreaks are Early Warning Systems (EWS).

questions.question: If you were a health officer, how would you monitor the occurrence of measles and detect an epidemic in your Sub-county
questions.explanation: Explanation: Tracking cases weekly (Surveillance data) allows for the detection of thresholds and epidemics.

options.text: C. A weekly record of cases of measles

questions.question: Which one of the following condition is active surveillance appropriate
questions.explanation: Explanation: Active surveillance is used for short periods during outbreaks, elimination programs, or when high quality data is needed quickly.

options.text: A. For programs with unlimited time
B. Routine evaluation of an ongoing program
C. In usual situations in a health facility
D. In unusual situations such as discovery

questions.question: One of the following is true about integrated disease and surveillance system. Which one is it
questions.explanation: Explanation: IDSR (Integrated Disease Surveillance and Response) aims to integrate resources (lab, transport, staff) for multiple diseases to increase efficiency, opposing vertical programs.

options.text: A. Different cadres carry out surveillance
B. Surveillance is carried out vertically
C. There is coordination to make best use of resources
D. The surveillance system is devolved

questions.question: During COVID 19, surveillance was carried out using one of the following methods
questions.explanation: Explanation: Contact tracing and testing (Active case detection) was the primary surveillance method. A, C, D are interventions, not surveillance methods.

options.text: D. Closure of schools and bars

questions.question: The main reason for quarantine during an outbreak is to
questions.explanation: Clarification: - Isolation: Separates sick from healthy (A). - Quarantine: Restricts movement of exposed (potentially ill) people for the duration of the incubation period to see if they become sick. Thus, preventing spread if they do.

options.text: A. To isolate the sick from healthy persons
B. To limit movement of health person to prevent exposure to disease
C. To confine unhealthy persons together for treatment
D. To ensure the incubation period of the disease has elapsed

questions.question: One of the following measures can be directed against domestic animals' reservoir in management of epidemic. Which one is it
questions.explanation: Explanation: Immunization of animal reservoirs reduces the pool of infection.

questions.question: Which one of the following statements is true about epidemic curve?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Epi curves are histograms. X-axis = Time (Date of onset), Y-axis = Cases.

options.text: A. It is usually in form of histogram
B. Number of cases are the horizontal axis
C. Date of onset is on the vertical axis
D. It is an important tool for surveillance

questions.question: For a spot map to be effective, it should be supplemented by use of the following
questions.explanation: Explanation: Spot maps show counts. To understand if a cluster is significant, you need to know the population density at that place, i.e., Place-specific rates.

questions.question: Epidemiologists and clinicians are concerned with disease and its control but they differ on how they view the patient. Give five differences on their approach to the patient. (5 marks)
questions.explanation: Clinician Epidemiologist Patient is the Individual. Patient is the Community/Population. Focuses on Diagnosis & Treatment. Focuses on Prevention & Control. Uses Lab/Imaging for assessment. Uses Surveillance/Biostatistics for assessment. Asks "What is wrong with this person?" Asks "Why is this disease in this population?" Outcome is Cure. Outcome is Reduction in incidence/prevalence.

questions.question: Consider a class with 100 enrolled students none of the students were ill at the beginning of the school year, on September 30th a total of 5 students reported having gastroenteritis. All the 5 continued to be ill on October 1st but all the 5 recovered within three days. On October 14th another 3 students developed gastroenteritis. All the students continued to be ill on October 15th but all the 3 recovered 5 days later. (5 marks)a) Calculate the prevalence of gastroenteritis on October 1stb) Calculate prevalence of gastroenteritis on October 30th (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: a) Prevalence on Oct 1st: Cases active on Oct 1st = The first 5 students (ill since Sept 30, recovered 3 days later, so still ill on Oct 1). Total Population = 100. Prevalence = 5/100 = 5%. b) Prevalence on Oct 30th: First 5 recovered by Oct 3rd. Next 3 developed illness Oct 14th, recovered 5 days later (Oct 19th). On Oct 30th, 0 students are ill. Prevalence = 0/100 = 0%.

options.text: Cases active on Oct 1st = The first 5 students (ill since Sept 30, recovered 3 days later, so still ill on Oct 1).

questions.question: Describe the main similarities and differences between incidence rate and cumulative incidence. (5 marks) (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Similarity: Both measure the occurrence of NEW cases of disease in a population over time (numerator is new cases). Difference (Denominator): Cumulative Incidence (Risk): Denominator is population at risk at the beginning of the period. Assumes fixed cohort. Range 0-1. Incidence Rate (Density): Denominator is Person-Time at risk. Handles dynamic populations and variable follow-up times. Range 0 to infinity.

options.text: Similarity: Both measure the occurrence of NEW cases of disease in a population over time (numerator is new cases).

Difference (Denominator): Cumulative Incidence (Risk): Denominator is population at risk at the beginning of the period. Assumes fixed cohort. Range 0-1. Incidence Rate (Density): Denominator is Person-Time at risk. Handles dynamic populations and variable follow-up times. Range 0 to infinity.
Cumulative Incidence (Risk): Denominator is population at risk at the beginning of the period. Assumes fixed cohort. Range 0-1.
Incidence Rate (Density): Denominator is Person-Time at risk. Handles dynamic populations and variable follow-up times. Range 0 to infinity.

questions.question: Using a diagram, illustrate the design of a case control study between exercise and myocardial infarction. (5 marks)
questions.explanation: [Diagram Structure - Retrospective] Time Direction: ← Investigating Past Exposure CASES (People with MI) ↙ ↘ Exercised No Exercise (Exposed) (Unexposed) CONTROLS (People without MI) ↙ ↘ Exercised No Exercise (Exposed) (Unexposed) Description: Start with cases (MI) and controls (No MI). Look back to see who exercised.

questions.question: Describe confounding using a diagram between coffee drinking(exposure), heart disease (disease) and tobacco use (confounder). (5 marks)
questions.explanation: [Triangle Diagram] Exposure (Coffee) ------> Outcome (Heart Disease) ↕ ↙ Confounder (Tobacco Use) Explanation: 1. Tobacco is associated with Coffee drinking (smokers drink more coffee). 2. Tobacco causes Heart Disease (independent risk factor). 3. Tobacco creates a false association between Coffee and Heart Disease if not controlled.

questions.question: During COVID 19 pandemic, physical and social distancing were main interventions advocated by Ministry of Health. Give the rationale behind this intervention. (5 marks) (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Mode of Transmission: COVID-19 is transmitted via respiratory droplets expelled when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks. Droplet Range: Larger droplets typically fall to the ground within 1-2 meters. Rationale: Maintaining distance (>1.5m) prevents healthy individuals from inhaling these droplets, breaking the chain of transmission at the "Mode of Transmission" link. It reduces the contact rate ($R_0$).

options.text: Mode of Transmission: COVID-19 is transmitted via respiratory droplets expelled when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks.
Droplet Range: Larger droplets typically fall to the ground within 1-2 meters.

questions.question: You have been appointed as the disease surveillance officer in a newly created Sub- County. Describe 5 major drawbacks you might encounter from the routine surveillance data. (5 marks) (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Underreporting: Many cases are not reported by facilities. Incompleteness: Forms often have missing data fields. Lack of Timeliness: Reports arrive too late for effective action. Inconsistency: Variation in case definitions used by different clinicians. Lack of Representativeness: Data mainly comes from public facilities, missing private sector and community cases.

options.text: Underreporting: Many cases are not reported by facilities.
Incompleteness: Forms often have missing data fields.
Lack of Timeliness: Reports arrive too late for effective action.
Inconsistency: Variation in case definitions used by different clinicians.
Lack of Representativeness: Data mainly comes from public facilities, missing private sector and community cases.

questions.question: An outbreak of cholera has occurred in four jurisdictions. Identify 5 ways you will actively detect the cases. (5 marks) (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Facility Visits: Regularly visiting health centers to review registers for acute watery diarrhea. Community Case Search: Using CHVs (Community Health Volunteers) to find sick people in households. Contact Tracing: Screening family and neighbors of confirmed cases. Laboratory Alert: Asking labs to immediately report any positive Vibrio cholerae samples. Rumor Surveillance: Monitoring social media and community leaders for reports of deaths or illness.

Community Case Search: Using CHVs (Community Health Volunteers) to find sick people in households.
Contact Tracing: Screening family and neighbors of confirmed cases.

questions.question: You are a newly posted lecturer tasked with teaching 3rd Year students in health records and information Epidemiology. The head of department has assigned you to teach descriptive studies. Explain 4 descriptive studies you will teach the students (10 marks) (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Case Reports: - Detailed description of a single patient with an unusual disease or association. - Useful for identifying new diseases (e.g., first AIDS cases). Case Series: - Description of a group/series of patients with similar diagnoses. - Defines clinical characteristics and distributions of a disease. Cross-Sectional Studies (Prevalence Studies): - A "snapshot" of a population at a single point in time. - Measures exposure and disease simultaneously. - Calculates Prevalence. Good for hypothesis generation. Ecological (Correlational) Studies: - Studies where the unit of analysis is populations/groups (e.g., countries) rather than individuals. - Compares aggregate exposure levels with aggregate disease rates (e.g., Fat consumption vs Breast cancer rates by country).

options.text: Case Reports: - Detailed description of a single patient with an unusual disease or association. - Useful for identifying new diseases (e.g., first AIDS cases).
Case Series: - Description of a group/series of patients with similar diagnoses. - Defines clinical characteristics and distributions of a disease.

Cross-Sectional Studies (Prevalence Studies): - A "snapshot" of a population at a single point in time. - Measures exposure and disease simultaneously. - Calculates Prevalence. Good for hypothesis generation.

Ecological (Correlational) Studies: - Studies where the unit of analysis is populations/groups (e.g., countries) rather than individuals. - Compares aggregate exposure levels with aggregate disease rates (e.g., Fat consumption vs Breast cancer rates by country).

questions.question: Discuss clinical trials under the following headlines (10 marks) a) Placebo b) Blinding c) Experimental group d) Control group e) Effectiveness trial (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: a) Placebo: An inert substance (e.g., sugar pill) indistinguishable from the active drug, given to the control group to eliminate the psychological effect of receiving treatment ("Placebo Effect"). b) Blinding (Masking): A procedure where subjects and/or investigators do not know who is receiving the treatment vs. placebo. Reduces information/observation bias. (Single, Double, Triple blind). c) Experimental group: The group of participants randomly assigned to receive the new intervention/treatment being tested. d) Control group: The group assigned to receive the standard treatment or placebo. They provide the baseline for comparison to determine if the new treatment works. e) Effectiveness trial (Pragmatic trial): A trial conducted under "real-world" conditions (not ideal/controlled) to see if the treatment works in routine practice with typical patients.
